title: Planned Syria Action Poses Test of Turkey’s Allegiances
text:
ISTANBUL—Turkey’s decision to launch a military offensive in northeastern Syria once American troops have withdrawn opens a new front in the eight-year Syrian conflict, testing the country’s influence in a volatile Middle East where the U.S. wants a diminished role and Russia a bigger one.

The planned offensive, which Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said could begin anytime, is designed to fulfill what Ankara has long outlined as a strategic security objective: prevent armed Kurdish forces the Turks view as a terrorist threat from getting a foothold along their southern border.

Mr. Erdogan has recently added another goal, saying the military incursion into Syria—Turkey’s third since 2016—would help create a “safe zone” to which millions of refugees who fled the war-ravaged country could return.

Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan speaking Monday during a press conference in Belgrade, Serbia. Photo: andrej cukic/Shutterstock

“Our aim is to shower [the region] with peace,” Mr. Erdogan said last week.

The Turkish military will cross into Syria through rural areas and make circular movements back toward the border to surround cities controlled by the Syrian Kurdish forces, according to Turkish officials. It wasn’t immediately clear how deeply into Syria they would seek to advance, the officials said.

Regardless of its scope, the plan is fraught with risks.

Financed, trained and armed by the U.S. to combat Islamic State, Syrian Kurdish forces have vowed to defend their territorial hold, including large border towns such as Kobani, raising fears of violent urban warfare and substantial civilian casualties. There is also a risk that the outlawed Kurdistan Workers’ Party, or PKK, which Ankara says is aligned with Syrian Kurdish forces, will intensify its own insurgency inside Turkey.

“We face threats from multiple fronts,” said Engin Ozkoc, a Turkish lawmaker affiliated with the opposition Republican People’s Party.

Related Video American troops began withdrawing from the Syria-Turkey border, marking a major shift in U.S. policy as Washington pulls back from a key partner in the fight against Islamic State—the Kurds—ahead of a Turkish offensive against them. Photo: Delil Souleiman/Getty Images

Once U.S. troops are gone, Turkey will have to collaborate with Russia, which has thrust itself into the role of leading power broker in Syria by throwing its military weight behind President Bashar al-Assad, allowing the regime to reclaim most provinces from rebel hands.

On Monday, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said Russia understood Turkey’s need to conduct a potential cross-border operation into Syria. “We know of and allow for Turkey’s actions to guarantee its security, its fight against terrorists that may be hiding in Syria,” Mr. Peskov told journalists.

The budding relationship between Turkey and Russia has been based largely on Ankara’s decision to purchase Russian S-400 system despite the threat of U.S. sanctions. That decision have worried officials at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, of which Turkey is a member, seeing it as a step that will push Ankara more firmly within Russia’s orbit.

A fighter with the Kurdish-led Syrian Democratic Forces standing on Monday at a post where U.S. troops were based near the Turkish border in Tel Abyad, Syria. Photo: Ahmad Baderkhan/Associated Press

But Russia, which is conducting airstrikes on the Syrian province of Idlib, the rebels’ last stronghold, has also warned Ankara against annexing more parts of Syria, saying the Assad regime was the only legitimate authority in the country. And Russia has maintained good relations with the Syrian Kurdish forces and their political wing, providing them with occasional support and allowing them to have a representative office in Moscow.

Yasar Yakis, a retired Turkish diplomat who held several posts in the Middle East, including in Damascus, said Turkey should be wary of having to deal face-to-face with Russia in Syria.

“Like the Americans, the Russians will want to hold the Kurdish card in their hands,” Mr. Yakis said. “It’s a powerful lever to keep Turkey’s ambitions in check.”

The Kurdish issue became a source of tension between Ankara and Washington in 2014 when the U.S. shifted tack in the Syrian conflict, steering away from supporting rebels against the Assad regime and bonding with Kurdish forces to fight Islamic State. That military cooperation became a source of exasperation for Turkey late last year, when President Trump declared Islamic State defeated.

Mr. Erdogan spent the following months urging Washington to part ways with its Kurdish allies and instead pair up with Turkey to create a buffer zone stretching from the Euphrates River to the Iraqi border that would be free of any armed Kurd.

In Washington, the request largely fell on deaf ears, in part because the Pentagon said it needed more time to eradicate remaining Islamic State threats, and because Turkey and the U.S. were sparring over the S-400 issue.

In August, nonetheless, the two countries began formal discussions on how to find a compromise in northeastern Syria.

By then, Mr. Erdogan was battling with falling approval ratings, which pollsters attribute to growing resentment among Turks over the presence of Syrian refugees in Turkey. In addition to repelling Kurdish militias away from its border, Turkey said it wanted to seize control of an 18-mile wide strip on inside Syria to relocate about half of the nearly four million Syrian refugees living in Turkey.

In September, Mr. Erdogan used his address during the United Nations General Assembly in New York to herald an even bigger plan. Brandishing a map of northeastern Syria, he proposed spearheading an effort to relocate three million Syrian refugees, including some from Europe, in the area. Turkey’s national housing agency followed with presentation of a $27 billion project to erect entire cities on the Syrian side of the border.

The plan has drawn only halfhearted support from the U.S., according to Turkish officials.

“We are really sincere about creating this ‘safe zone’,” Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlut Cavusoglu said last week. “But we do not see the same sincerity on the U.S. side.”

Western diplomats say the Turkish idea of sending millions of Syrians back home isn’t realistic in its current form. They say the U.S. and the European Union could hardly support building cities in a complete legal vacuum, since most land owners have been displaced by war. They also warn against the risk of altering Syria’s ethnic fabric by sending refugees to regions different from their province of origin.

“It’s ludicrous,” one Western diplomat said.

—Thomas Grove in Moscow contributed to this article.

Write to David Gauthier-Villars at David.Gauthier-Villars@wsj.com
